title: How much sense does it make to buy a $10,000 smart watch when there's going to be newer version of it every year? - Quora

response.answer_text: What makes you think they'll be a newer version every year? Because that's what happened with Smartphones, Tablets, and Computers?  Even if there is a new version every year, that doesn't make your current version obsolete. I never quite understood all the people who complained when the iPad 4 was released 8 months after the iPad 3. My iPad 3 still worked fine and continues to work to this day. It didn't become obsolete. It still performs all the tasks I wanted it to do. It wasn't made useless by a new model coming out.  With the Apple Watch (I assume you're talking about that) it's even more that way. The Watch is basically an extension of the iPhone with a lot of sensors. So they could upgrade it with better sensors and better battery life, but your old Watch will continue to function just fine and will probably even get a software update. Additionally, if you bought the $1000 or great one you weren't buying it for functionality and more as a status symbol. It will still work for that.  Smartphones generally have a 2 year life cycle as dictated by the cell phone contract. Tablets we're still learning what their life cycle is but it could definitely be as high as 5 years. I think the Watch could be even higher as it will be hard to make an upgrade compelling.

Sense?  Logical rationale?   By most standards there isn't any.  However there will be an emotive tug. This is at once simple and complex, but bound up in this will be a desire to be seen wearing this thing.  Depreciation and inevitable technical obsolescence are not part of this equation. So you look at sense/logic from an emotional perspective.  How will the owner of the circa-2015 watch feel when the 2016 model, a thinner, sexier, perhaps more functional piece hits the runway?  Will they feel that their watch is still a classic timeless accessory?  Or will they feel some level of inferiority to walk around with a chunky out-of-date wrist brick?  I personally suspect the latter. All said and done, for someone wanting to wrap $10k around their wrist this makes perfect sense.
